title: R Kelly ordered to use music royalties to pay child support bills
text:
R Kelly has struggled to pay child support in the past (Picture: Getty Images)

R Kelly has reportedly been ordered to use his music royalties to pay his monthly child support bills.

The I Believe I Can Fly singer has allegedly struggled to make the monthly payments of $23,833 ($17,000) to his ex-wife Andrea for the care of their three children.

According to TMZ, new court documents reveal that a judge has advised R Kelly to use the money he earns from companies like BMI and Sony for the publishing of his back catalogue.

However, he’s reportedly asked the judge to lower the payments.

Streaming of R Kelly’s music is believed to have decreased somewhat this year in the midst of the sex abuse allegations against him, and critics have supported the #MuteRKelly movement in an attempt to silence his music.

R Kelly, 52, is father to three children – Joann (aka Buku Abi), 21, Jay, 19, and Robert Kelly Jr, 17, from his 13-year marriage to Drea, which ended in 2009.

Earlier this year, the R&B singer ended up in jail after failing to make the child support payments.

But in May, he managed to avoid a lengthy stint behind bars after coughing up $62,000 (£47,000) in back payments.

Andrea Kelly shares three children with the singer (Picture: Rex Features)

At the time, it was reported that R Kelly made the staggering payment using a cheque at the Daley Center in Chicago, Illinois. Although it was claimed he owed a further $32,000 (£24,000) in interest on the child support, while Drea also requested extra child support to cover their daughter’s secondary education expenses.

Drea’s lawyer told reporters: ‘Ms Kelly appreciates the fact that Mr Kelly is not going to have any special protection above and beyond what anyone else has.

‘[If] he doesn’t take his responsibilities seriously, doesn’t comply with his obligations to his children, it’s gonna get filed and people will know.’

R Kelly is currently in jail after being charged with multiple counts of aggravated sexual abuse. He has pleaded not guilty to all charges.

Previous court documents showed the severity of R Kelly’s financial difficulties with only $625 (£479) in his bank account.

Documents also show that a different bank account owned by Kelly was overdrawn by $13 (£9.91).

In addition to his child support payments, the singer apparently owed his landlord a backlog of $200,000 (£152,508) in rent and faced eviction from his New York home if he didn’t pay up.

Drea appeared in the critically-acclaimed Lifetime documentary Surviving R Kelly, which featured women recounting their claims of sexual abuse allegedly at the hands of the singer.
